text:
PETRA PARIKOVA: My
name is Petra Parikova. I'm the Associate Director
at Stanford Center for Professional Development
for our Computer Science,

Cybersecurity, Artificial
Intelligence Programs and Courses. And together with me
we have John Mitchell

and Mark Mitchell. It's actually accidental that
the surname is the same, which is actually a fun fact.

And they will tell you
more about themselves. But just to introduce
them very briefly, John is our great professor
of computer science

and by courtesy also electrical
engineering and education at Stanford University.

And he's also currently the
chair of the Computer Science Department. And Mark Mitchell, he
has so much experience.

It was so hard to pick one. So I would just say like
he's computer scientist,

entrepreneur, investor,
really excited about the topics of
blockchain and Web3. And we are so grateful that
they both took the time

to join us today. Thank you so much
for joining us. With that, I will hand
it off to Mark and John.

Thank you. JOHN MITCHELL: All right. Good morning or good
afternoon, a good evening,

wherever you are in the world. It's great to get started
and have a conversation this morning here in California
about blockchain and Web3.

Very happy to be joined by Mark. Let us each give a little
short introduction to ourselves

and then we're going to
talk about some applications and some main ideas and
give an overview for 15,

20 minutes, maybe half an hour. And then we'd love to
hear questions from anyone

in the audience about what you'd
like to hear about and make this interactive if possible.

So just to background, I've been
a professor of computer science here for a couple of decades.

I worked on programming
languages, computer security, network security. I spent a little
bit of time working

on educational technology
and things of that sort. And blockchain,
Web3 really relates

to a lot of the
interests and things that I've worked on
over many decades.

You'll see there's a
contract languages, different programming languages
are involved in blockchain

and the underlying mechanism
of consensus protocols is related to network
protocols, network security, use

of cryptography. In this particular
area, one thing I did was take about 18 months to
work part time with the effort

that Facebook initiated, was
called Libra for a while then Novi. I spent about 18 months
there very part time

just trying to see if I could
be helpful and follow along on that. So that was a major
effort to build

a new blockchain, a
new cryptocurrency, built some
applications around it.

And of course involved in
courses in seminar talks on the subject. So I don't know everything.

It's a big area, things
are moving quickly, but we'll try to give you an
orientation to the main issues

and focus on applications
and why this can be interesting and exciting.

Mark. MARK MITCHELL: Yeah. So as Petra said, John
and I are not related but we do have the same haircut
and so we have that in common.

I was one of John's
students at Stanford and I hate to tell you John
it was more than a couple of decades ago.

But it's a while. And as Petra
mentioned, since then I

left Stanford I didn't
ever get my PhD, I went off and started a
startup and eventually sold it.

I ran a division in a big
public company for a while and then I got into
investing in startups

and serving on the
boards of startups. And so now I've wandered
back and stitched the two

halves of my career together. I'm now at SRI International,
which is a nonprofit research

lab. And so there I do
computer science research. But I'm also working with them
on spinning out technologies

and investing in companies that
can make use of SRI technology. So that's a fun bit.

And both my research
way back when with John was on
cryptography and security

and obviously blockchain. Relates to that. So I've had an interest in this
sector since it got started.

And I have invested in a few
Web3 or crypto companies. But mostly I haven't.

And so I've avoided losing
money on some bad crypto deals

and I've also avoided making
money on good crypto deals. So like John, I would not
claim to be the world's deepest

expert on any of this thing
but I have a little bit more of perhaps the business
perspective on it.

So John if we're going
to talk about Web3, I guess we got to
start with Web1. You want to-- JOHN MITCHELL: Right.

So this is just perspective. It's really to explain the
term Web3 and why it's used.

So if you just think
back in history or look back at the way
the web has developed,

the web came into being
after the internet was there in place as a way of
building a application layer

and exchange of information
over the internet. Web1 was simply the
protocols and tools

for being able to
write web pages, link them together,
and read them.

So it was created
by physicists, they had physics experiments
and papers and documents

and pictures and data
that they wanted to share. You could create a web page
and link the different parts

together. But there was not an
interactive media. It was basically authors
would build stuff

and readers would use
different means to find them. If you were following
this back then,

it was a struggle where we're
going to use directories. Yahoo was a big human
created index into the web

and AltaVista and Google
were these automated search. We didn't know at the time which
was going to be more practical.

Of course in retrospect,
it's obvious there's so much on the web.

No work single person in our
group of 50 or 100 people could write an index
to all the things

you'd want to find on the web. The automation really took over. And I just mentioned that
just to remind everyone,

remind ourselves that in the
early stage of a technology, you don't know which
of the parts of it

are going to become the
most successful later on. So moving through
this Web2 is really

where user input
started to be possible. It's the form field in a web
page or form field in HTML

if you're familiar with that. Where the user input, then
sites can become interactive.

You could put up
a questionnaire. People could write
things into it. You could have social
media, because where

different users of
a site contribute and add content to it.

And along with that came
this notion of who's writing what, authentication,
the passwords, HTTPS, SSL,

the use of websites
certificates and authentication, both directions so that users
could authenticate themselves

to sites. Sites are effectively
authenticated by certificates. And that gives us some
nice infrastructure

for e-commerce, social
media, and all these things that have had massive effects
not always uniformly regarded

as positive effect. But technology just
keeps marching along and it upsets our world
and changes things.

And if you wish we all had
news printed newspapers and you don't like social media,
I think we're out of luck.

This is the world we live
in and it's different. And the same thing
can happen with Web3, if you like going to the
bank on your neighborhood.

Maybe that's great but maybe
it'll go away for some reason. So Web3 is really about--

the term I think refers to
the application layer features

and functionality
and potential that can be built using blockchain
as an underlying mechanism.

So what does that give us
as a sum of options here? In Web2 and
traditional websites,

each page is hosted
by one provider, somebody wrote that, they put
it on their server, that's

where it lives. With a blockchain, the
ownership of the content can be distributed and
managed in a certain way.

And we have these
things that we'll talk about in more detail for
asserting ownership, exchanging

ownership, creating markets
for buying, selling, trading,

bartering and using
different tokens that

represent ownership or
membership in some group and so on. So I hope that's a helpful
explanation of the term market.

I missed something in the Web3. I feel like I wandered
around the topic. It's a little hard
to define crisply.

MARK MITCHELL: Well. No, I think he did good. And maybe we go
to the next slide and we'll get into some
of the specific Web3 terms

and that'll help
clarify it a little bit. So at the lowest level,
we have this thing

called the blockchain. And this is what's
underlying Web3. There are a lot of words on this
slide, but I think some of them

are important. So the blockchain is a
verifiable public ledger. What does that mean?

Well, the verifiable part means
any person can come and look at that blockchain and be
convinced that it's authentic.

The blockchain
itself is a ledger, so it's something where we're
adding more information to it,

nothing's ever removed from it. We keep adding
things to the end. And the public means that
anybody can add things

and anybody can verify
what's been added. And that verifiability allows
us to say, who added it

and that it was a legitimate
thing to add to the blockchain, it really was added.

Now, part of what
the trick in this is the distribution aspect. So there's no single
party, no person,

no company that's
maintaining the blockchain. At least when we talk
about public blockchains,

it's literally thousands or
tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands of computers
running all over the world.

And there's some complicated
cryptography and math to make that work in a reliable
and reasonably secure way.

And I'll say reasonably because
there are issues around that. But that is the goal.

So one particular use of the
blockchain is cryptocurrency. And I think a lot of people
conflate cryptocurrency

and blockchain as the
same, but they're not. Cryptocurrency is just one use. So in cryptocurrency,
blockchains, the thing

that's being added
to the chain is who owns what piece of money? What Bitcoin or
what piece either?

And as those move around,
as they get transferred, as people pay each
other, the blockchain keeps track of who has it now?

Where did it go? Who transferred it to whom? But there are other uses. And in fact, most of what
we're going to focus on today

is not cryptocurrencies
as a blockchain. Another term that's
part of this technology

stack that underlies
Web3 is smart contracts. We all know what contracts are. We've all signed contracts.

But normally contracts
are on pieces of paper or they're electronic documents.

But they don't do
anything by themselves, they're just documents. And then if somebody has some
obligation under the contract

and they don't live up to
it, you have to sue them. You have to go to court. You have to find some way
of enforcing the contract.

These smart contracts
are programs that are themselves
embedded on the blockchain.

And they run just like
any computer program runs. So the program
might say that John

is going to transfer some
Bitcoins to me or some Ether to me when some
condition is fulfilled.

And that program just runs when
that condition is fulfilled and the transfer is completed.

So the contracts are
smart because they execute themselves.

And then finally, the last term
on the slide here is token. And so we have these records
on the blockchain that

correspond to
sometimes real things in the real world
like real estate

or cars or jet
planes or paintings. But sometimes they
correspond to something

purely digital like a
piece of digital artwork or the right to play a
particular piece of music

or things like this. But those tokens can be
traded around for other tokens

or for cryptocurrency or
they can be smart contracts, can move them from
place to place.

So these are all some
of the important terms that are part of the
technology underlying Web3.
But there are a lot more terms. John, do you want to-- JOHN MITCHELL: Well, so--

So just for pacing
and to give you.

The audience a little
more sense of overview we just wanted to make sure
that we had defined in some way

the key terms
we're going to use. We're going to get back to
explaining many of the things we alluded to in more
detail through examples.

And then this slide is even
more the landscape and not

something we're going to go
into in detail right now. But later on, if
you have a question,

if you'd like us
to dig in on one of these portions of this
picture, then please do.

We'll have time for questions
and audience input as we go. This is a picture
that we created

to try to put some
things in order. So the key idea is this
notion of blockchain.

A ledger, a write only
verifiable data structure and then many of the
different ways it can be used.

On the left, that
branch represents, how does a blockchain work? So we could dig
into the technology.

There's open blockchains. Anyone could try to become a
maintainer of the blockchain

or closed. It's a private community of
banks say that runs a bank.

Blockchain. Then there's ledger. These as we go to
the right, it becomes

more in the application area. What can you do with a ledger? What can we do with
something where

you can write stuff
and the things you write never go
away but somebody else can write another thing
that could supersede that.

So we'll talk about
some applications there. One big application
of course and what

got this whole area really going
was the financial application, the invention of
Bitcoin, which is

a clever idea both in its
technology and its use.

There are lots of
things there about how currency works,
decentralized finance,

different financial
infrastructure based on this. We'll say a little bit about
DAO distributed organizations

that have usually financial. Impact and then Web3
is the broader term

for the-- as yet not
fully defined future, all the ways you can use tokens,
create exchanges, and so on.

So I hope that's useful
as where we could go. And if we had a week, we dig
into all of these things.

This brief webinar
an hour at most, we're not going to be able
to dig into all of these.

But we wanted at this
point to just give you of an overview of
what some of the things are that you might
have heard about

or might be particularly
interested in and how they relate
to other concepts. Mark, any further
comments on this outline?

MARK MITCHELL: No, I
think that's great.

So maybe I'll talk about-- I happen to notice we have
a little window that we can see here that's
got questions coming in

and we're going to take
questions properly at the end. But one of the
questions that came in is, is Web3 a solution
in search of a problem?

That's a really good
question and I don't actually know if anybody
knows the answer. There are a lot
of people who are

confident they know the
answer one way or the other. But I think the proof
is in the pudding.

We don't have much in the way
of established Web3 utility

at this point. But we sure have
a lot of interest and a lot of money
flowing into it.

So I think a lot of people
have the feeling that there ought to be something there.

And this is an example of
something that might be there. So we all have medical records.

And your medical records
come from lots of places. You go to the doctor, you have
the doctor writes things down,

you go and get an x-ray,
they put the x-ray in the medical record. You get your blood tested, they
put that in the medical record.

And this comes in over
a long period of time. I'm 49 years old, so my
medical record I suppose

goes back 49 years
and hopefully they'll be maybe another
49 years of data

on the next part of
my medical record. So that has to all be kept
track of over this long period

of time with lots of different
sources of information. And one of the interesting
things about it

is, I really don't want
most people to know what's in my medical record,
it's private, it's my business.

But of course I do need
my doctor to know it or my pharmacist to know it and
to some extent need my health

insurance company to know it. And if I'm in an
emergency situation, if I'm in a car crash
or something like that,

I want the EMTs
that are helping me to have access to that record. And I'd really like that record
to be available worldwide.

If I'm on vacation in
Thailand or someplace, I would like the
people there to be

able to get my medical record. So the problem here, if we
look at the current world,

is that data is generally living
in some individual companies

servers. It happens, I'm a Kaiser
person, so Kaiser's got

my medical record. I don't think there's
any easy way for the EMTs to get at that data.

They'd have to somehow
get through Kaiser. It's not going to be
there immediately. It's not easy to access.

And it's not easy for
somebody in foreign country, I might be visiting to add
anything to the medical record.

So that's a real problem
and it's the thing that perhaps blockchain
could help with.

The blockchain is designed
to have this long lifetime.

The data is distributed
around the world on all these different servers, so
presumably it's harder for it

to be disappeared
or to be hacked. It's auditable, we can know
who added things to it,

and when they
added things to it, and control access to
it in various ways.

So at least potentially,
I think blockchain could help with this problem. John, what do you think?

JOHN MITCHELL: Great idea. I thought we'd just
review what are some of the features
of blockchain

that might be helpful
in figuring out. Is this an advance here or not? Why would blockchain be
Helpful And just to review

what we alluded to,
blockchain provides this trusted public ledger
that's decentralized.

And one reason
that this might be applicable to the
medical record case is, it's not clear who really
owns your medical record

or who should be the
central person that agency that controls it. It might be great if that's
spread out and distributed

all over the world. The way Mark mentioned,
if you're on vacation,

you're injured, you have an
allergy to a certain treatment

or drug or something
that someone might give you it's
great if that's available in many places.

So in asking, is
blockchain going to help? Its do we need a
decentralized solution

and the property that
information is persistent or it's like a
ledger in that sense.

So what do you think about
the medical application

there, Mark, does it
meet these criteria? MARK MITCHELL: I think it does. I mean, I think these are, to
go back to that question of,

is Web3 a solution in
search of a problem? I think it is a solution
to a real problem.

And I think the
problems that it's going to be useful for solving
are those where you have data

that has to live a long time and
there's no one that you really trust to hold on to it.

And you do need to
be able to figure out who added things to
that data set and when

so that you can do audits. And I think medical
records are appropriate, fit those criteria.

And I think the blockchains are
even more useful when we really have to be able to
verify that data

or figure out if there's
some value in them. Medical records may or may
not have the value part of it

but they might. JOHN MITCHELL: So let me talk
about another idea that's similar.

And this is something that
has had some traction. I was on the Steering Committee
for an effort associated

with the US Department
of Education to explore blockchains
and education.

And the organizational
structure was that the Department
of Ed in collaboration

with the American Council on
Education solicited proposals.

The proposals were to get
funding to build prototypes. And then four prototypes were
built and tested and used.

And it was meant to test
the value of blockchain in education. So let me just tell
you about two of them.

One was for students
in a particular region.

I think Dallas was the area. And so someone might
finish high school,

go to community college, often
community college students go to more than one community
college over a few years,

then they want to transfer
to a four-year college and they want to
get a degree based on transfer of those credits.

So in that case,
just the way Mark was explaining for
medical records, no single organization
feels responsible for all

of the educational
information, all of the grades and transcripts for a person
who's transferred from one

school to another to another. But in the region, Dallas it's
great to have this capacity.

And it helps build the
economy and provide education and certifiable
skills for future employers

to have that so they see there
that a distributed shared infrastructure
that's trustworthy.

No one wants to give
a degree if someone lied about their transcript. We want to know that
that's valid and so on.

That's one application. Another one that I thought
was very interesting had to do with
credentials for teachers.

Teachers are supposed
to go and have continuing education regularly.

And they again can go to
many different organizations for that.

One of the blockchain pilots was
to build a national repository

of teacher certification
credentials, including this
continuing education.

In that way, teachers could
have all of their information in one place. This had an unexpected
consequence.

And I think this is
partly to that question, is this a solution in
search of a problem?

One of the things that you look
for in an emerging technology is, you suddenly
have applications

that you didn't think of
at all but are actually extremely valuable. In this educational
certification

for teachers, what the
blockchain suddenly became was a way for schools to find
candidates and hire teachers.

So if you had a biology teacher
in high school in one city

resign and leave, you need to
hire another biology teacher, where would you find one?

This blockchain with all this
information about teachers and who's up to date on
their continuing education

provided a great way for
school systems and districts to go out, reach out,
and find teachers.

That of course is valuable
for the teacher's who are seeking jobs
and get job offers. And it accelerated and improved
the infrastructure there

in a way that no
one had anticipated when they proposed this. But I thought it's an example of
how the technology was useful.

Is that it gave us these
unexpected consequences that in this case were very positive.

MARK MITCHELL: And I think
that the verifiability is really important because
you could go and look at that.

Someone sends you a resume and
you have to figure out what on the resume you believe
and what you don't.

So having something
where I don't have to call your
references, you have a signed
cryptographically secure thing

that says you got this
credential from so and so. That's interesting. JOHN MITCHELL: All right.

Shall we talk for a few minutes
about applications in banking? I think there are
many but I just

wanted to touch on
this a little bit. If I wanted to send Mark
a little bit of money.

We went out for coffee, he paid
for it, I want to pay him back or you can imagine something
else, the current mechanism

for me to send money from
one person to another, the automated
clearinghouse mechanism

is really very complicated. It has many different layers. It takes about three days
for me to transfer money from

my account to Mark's. Could we speed that up? Could we make it more efficient? Could we introduce
new technology

that would modernize
that aspect of banking? A lot of questions like that.

Which ones do interest you
most Mark around this area? MARK MITCHELL: Well, I guess,
I think that direct money

transfer is one. But I think there
are a lot of things that are analogous to that. When you buy and sell stocks,
you have the same settlement

process. You put an order in and
it's not for two or three days that the stock is actually
registered in your name.

And if you sell the stock,
it's a couple of days before you get the funds. And all of these systems
have the same problem

that there are these multiple
layers and cooperating parties that need some central trusted
clearinghouse in your banking

diagram. It's the central bank and
in the securities context it's different.

Central clearinghouses, but
they need these organizations to record the stock is no
longer in Mark's account,

it's now in John's
account, the money is no longer in John's account,
it's in Mark's account. And getting that all recorded
is time consuming and expensive.

So there's certainly a
potential for accelerating all of those transfers,
particularly where they

involve some legal ownership. So another thing I know people
like that a lot is real estate

and go and buy real estate. You have a title
company involved to make sure that the money's
been provided from the buyer

and that the seller has done
all the things they need to do to transfer
ownership to the new buyer

and then the title company
also goes and records who owns the thing on
a public ledger, which

is the public ledger
maintained by the county of who owns what parcels.

but it's a paper ledger or
a computer ledger maintained by a single party not a
decentralized auditable

ledger in this way. JOHN MITCHELL: Now I want
to make one more point and then maybe we'll go on
to contracts and DAO and some

of our futuristic things. The reason why it takes three
days for a bank transfer

partly is just the
way things are set up. But partly there is some
fraud detection and ability

to roll back or not complete
fraudulent transactions. Sometimes the multiple layers
check and recheck, send

and confirm and send
again two phase commit, other things that
are in these systems

do serve a useful
purpose in addition to slowing things down. And when we
modernize banking, we

don't want to have more
theft than we have now, more fraud than we have
now, identity theft suddenly

empty your bank account. There's a bunch of
interesting security problems to solve as we think
about modernizing banking

or any other infrastructure
with more efficient contemporary technology.

Should we say a little bit about
contracts and how they work? And then maybe those are a
good example to think about.

What do you think is important? MARK MITCHELL: Sure. I mean, I think this
ties into the point you just were making
about the benefits of some

of the slowness. Smart contracts are,
as we said earlier, they're really programs
that execute automatically

and they can transfer
money around. And there are good
examples of errors

in those contracts resulting
in large hundreds of millions of dollars of transfers that
shouldn't have happened.

And there is no easy
mechanism for undoing them. There isn't that slowness
that allows you to notice

that something's going wrong. There isn't even necessarily
anybody to sue afterwards

to get the money back. So there are real risks
with these smart contracts.

Yeah. JOHN MITCHELL: I mean,
we can take an example. I'm going to loan you
money and you're going to pay it back to me over time.

So what we write into
the blockchain is,

I'm going to add a
start date, maybe you choose the start date,
a certain amount of money

is transferred from my
account to your account. And then let's say
monthly thereafter,

you pay me back a certain
amount of money each month until we've reached
some agreed upon point,

which gives me back
my principal and maybe a little bit of interest. So we would write that as a
contract on the blockchain,

it would execute automatically
if we set it up that way and do the transfer.

But if there was a bug
in it, what would happen? Suppose I transferred
twice as much money

as I expected because there
was a bug in it or the payment amount was wrong, or it went
on longer than we planned.

Those kind of bugs,
somebody would end up a winner and somebody
would end up a loser. In this blockchain world,
what happens in that case?

MARK MITCHELL: Yeah. Well, I mean, what
happens there's generally one of two things, either
if you're the loser

or you just lose because the
contract was the contract. Or sometimes the community
that's running the blockchain

decides to essentially
invalidate the contract and they do what's
called the hard fork

and they go and just make
like it never happened. Of course, that has the
risk of being political.

There's not a judge or a jury or
a governmental system in there. So it could be also that the
contract is totally valid

but they decide that they
don't like me and they like you and then they might undo
the transaction in some way.

So there are a lot of things. Real world contracts have
all these fuzzy bits in them where you have to make
reasonable efforts

and somebody has to do
something unless there's a unforeseeable
circumstance, an act of war,

or a natural disaster. All those things get
written into these contracts and they're intentional fuzz
to work around situations

we can't anticipate up front. And one of the challenges
with smart contracts is right now they're
pretty black and white.

And if we're going
to use them for some of these more
complicated situations, we'll have to figure out how
to deal with some of that fuzz.

JOHN MITCHELL: Do
we talk about DAO? What do you think about DAOs? MARK MITCHELL: Well, I guess
we should define them first.

So normally if you
have a company, you have a bunch of shareholders
that own the company or if you have some
other organization

you may have a board of
directors for that organization that control the organization
and what it can do.

And the idea of a
DAO is that instead of doing that will
divide up the ownership

or control amongst a bunch
of people or entities based on how many tokens they own
in some particular thing.

And in many cases, then there
are smart contracts in place that say if those
tokens are voted

to change the rules in some
way, then the rules change.

In this it's also-- it's very powerful, it means
we can start something, looks

like a corporation or a company
of some kind with people all over the world without
any government being involved,

et cetera. But it also means
that if somebody gets too many of
those tokens, they

can change the rules in
pretty surprising ways. JOHN MITCHELL: So
maybe one example

that occurs to me now
seeing the city DAO example is something like
timeshare arrangement.

You can go buy from Marriott
or some other large company, timeshare in a pool of
say vacation properties.

And you buying the timeshare,
you pay a certain amount of money up front, you pay
a certain amount each year,

you might pay a little bit of
